inlineContent.text: Interactive tutorials are a great way to present your technology to readers.
In this section we will add a tutorial that guides readers through creating and customizing a
Pssst‚Ä¶ All the learning material you have been reading up until now was made using DoCC. That means that this is a DocC tutorial about making DocC tutorials! ü§ØüòÉ
The table of contents provides an overview of the tutorials offered in your documentation.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
The section will reference images that are included in the
branch. Without these images and files you will not be able to complete this tutorial. You may refer to
tutorial for instructions on adding an image yourself.
Right-click the documentation catalog in the Project navigator and select New Folder.
Name the new folder ‚ÄúTutorials‚Äù.
Right-click the Tutorials folder and select New File.
Choose Tutorial Table of Contents File in the Template picker and select Next.
Name the file ‚ÄúMeet BuildABuddyKit.tutorial‚Äù and select Create.
Select ‚ÄúMeet BuildABuddyKit.tutorial‚Äù in the Project navigator.
The template contains three directives:
, and
. The
directive contains the structure of the tutorial, the
directive describes the tutorial, and the
directive references step-by-step pages of the tutorial.
Add a name to your series of tutorials. This is typically the same as your product.
Add a title to your series of tutorials. This will be displayed prominently in the table of contents.
Provide an engaging text that describes the tutorials.
Add an image to the table of contents that catches the reader‚Äôs attention.
If you checked out the
branch earlier then the image is already located in the Resources folder. You may refer to
tutorial for instructions on adding an image yourself.
Add a name to the chapter.
Chapters group related tutorials. This chapter will explain users the essentials of using the BuildABuddyKit framework so we will name it ‚ÄúBuildABuddyKit Essentials‚Äù.
Add a descriptive text to the chapter.
Add an image to the chapter. Chapters must have an image. Xcode will show a warning when building the documentation if a chapter does not have an image.
Remove the tutorial reference. We will add it again once we have written the tutorial to reference.
Finally, build the documentation and select ‚ÄúMeet BuildABuddyKit‚Äù under Workspace Documentation to view the table of contents.
Xcode will show a warning because the chapter does not contain any tutorial and for the same reason the table of contents will not show the chapter. We will address this in the next section.
In this section we will add a tutorial that guides readers throug creating and customizing an instance of
and make it available through the table of contents.
You are encouraged to build the documentation as you go through the following steps to see how the tutorial changes along the way.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
The section will reference images and files that are included in the
branch. Without these images and files you will not be able to complete this tutorial.
Notice that the Tutorials folder contains nine Swift files. These are the code snippets that will be used in our tutorial. Creating the Swift files is a detail that is left out of this tutorial.
It is recommended that you spend a minute browsing the Swift files to notice that each file builds upon the previous. For example,
contains a SwiftUI view and it‚Äôs body and
adds a property to the same view.
Right-click the Tutorials folder and select New File.
Choose Tutorial File in the Template picker and select Next.
Name the file ‚ÄúCustomizing a Buddy.tutorial‚Äù and select Create.
Select ‚ÄúMeet BuildABuddyKit.tutorial‚Äù in the Project navigator.
Add a reference to the newly created tutorial.

You are encouraged to continously build the documentation to see how changes affect the resulting documentation. Now is a good time to build the docuemntation and visit the table of contents as it will now show the chapter.
Select ‚ÄúCustomizing a Buddy.tutorial‚Äù in the Project navigator.
The template contains several directives, including
, and
. We will go over each of them in the following steps.
Add an estimated time it takes to complete the tutorial. The is specified in minutes and displayed both in the tutorial and in the table of contents.
Add the title of the tutorial.
Add a description informing users what they will do in this tutorial.
Remove the image from the intro.
The image is optional and while it looks great to have one in the tutorial, it serves little purpose so we will leave it out.
Add a title to the section.
The
directive is used to show a unit of work that consists of text and media. A tutorial must contain at least one section.
Add a text that describes what readers will do in this section of the tutorial.
The
directive groups a text and an image or video. A section should contain one of these otherwise the section will not be shown in the tutorial.
Add an image to the
directive.
Add the first step that the reader must perform inside the first
directive within the
directive.
A section should contain exactly one
directive that in turn contains one or more
directives. Each individual step (represented by a
directive) represents a small task that the user should perform.
Replace the
directive within the first step with a
directive.
The
directive takes two parameters: the name of the file which will be displayed in the tutorial and a reference to the Swift file containing the code to be displayed in the tutorial.
If you checked out the
branch earlier then the Swift file is already located in the Tutorials folder.
Add a description to the second step.
Add a
directive to the second step.
Because the
directive references a file named ContentView.swift, which is the same name as in the previous step, DocC will automatically render the diff between the code in this step and in the previous step.
Add an
directive as a child of the
directive.
Because the
is nested within the
directive, it will be rendered as a preview that can be expanded and collapsed.
Add the remaining steps to the section by copying them from the code on the right-hand side and inserting it into your tutorial.

Apple‚Äôs tutorials tend to start with a section detailing how readers should create an Xcode project. We will do the same in our tutorial and at the same time let readers know how to add the BuildABuddyKit package to our package.
Copy the new section from the code on the right-hand side and add it to your tutorial.
Finally, build the documentation and view the tutorial.
How many chapters can a series of tutorials contain?
There can only be one.
Oops, that is not correct.
Up to five.
Sorry, that is not correct.
As many as the developer would like.
That is correct! You can add all the chapters you would like.
Which unit do we use to specify the estimated time it takes to complete a tutorial?
Seconds.
Oops, that is not correct.
Minutes.
That is correct! The table of contents displays the estimated time it takes to complete a tutorial to set people‚Äôs expectations straight.
Hours.
Sorry, that is not correct.
Which directive can we use to show syntax highlighted Swift code next in a step?
That is correct!
Bummer! That is not correct.
Sorry, that is not correct.
How can we display a preview next to a code snippet?
That is correct!
Bummer! That is not correct.
Sorry, that is not correct.

content: This tutorial will guide you through adding BuildABuddyKit to your project and customizing your first buddy.
Create an instance of `Buddy` and customize it.
This tutorial will guide you through adding BuildABuddyKit to your project and customizing your first buddy.
Create an instance of `Buddy` and customize it.
Add a private property named `buddy` that returns an instance of `Buddy`.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-07.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a globe icon and the text \"Hello, world!\".")
Add a `BuddyImage` and pass it the value of `buddy`.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-08.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy.")
Start customizing the buddy by changing the skin tone.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-09.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a changed skin tone.")
Change the hair of the buddy.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-10.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with changed hair.")
Change the mouth of the buddy.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-11.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a changed mouth.")
Notice that the color of the front of the shirt and the color of the sleeves can be specified independently.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-12.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a new shirt.")
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-13.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with new pants.")
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-14.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with new shoes.")

content: This tutorial will guide you through adding BuildABuddyKit to your project and customizing your first buddy.
@Section(title: "Create a new project and add BuildABuddyKit") {
Create and configure an Xcode project that uses BuildABuddyKit.
Open Xcode and either click "Create a new Xcode project" in Xcode‚Äôs startup window, or choose File > New > Project.

@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-01.png, alt: "A screenshot of the Welcome to Xcode screen, which displays when you open Xcode. There are three options to choose from when you open Xcode: Create a new Xcode project, Clone an existing project, and Open a project or file. The first option ‚Äî¬†Create a new Xcode project ‚Äî¬†is highlighted.")
In the template selector, select iOS as the platform, select the App template, and then click Next.

@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-02.png, alt: "A screenshot of the template selector sheet in Xcode. In the top row, iOS is selected as the platform. In the Application section, App is selected as the template; there is a highlight placed over the Next button at the lower-right of the sheet.")
Enter "BuddyCreator" as the product name, select "SwiftUI" for the interface, and select "Swift" for the language, and click Next. Choose a location to save the BuddyCreator project on your Mac.

@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-03.png, alt: "A screenshot of the project sheet, which shows the Product Name for the app being built as TextCompanion. The interface is set to Storyboard, and the language is set to Swift.")
Add BuildABuddyKit as a Swift Package to your project by right-clicking your project in the Project navigator and selecting "Add Packages‚Ä¶"
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-04.png, alt: "A screenshot of the Project navigator, which shows right-click menu with the Add Packages menu item highlighted.")

Search for "https://github.com/simonbs/BuildABuddyKit" and select BuildABuddyKit in the search results. Specify a dependency rule, select the TextCompanion project under "Add to Project", and then select "Add Package".

@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-05.png, alt: "A screenshot of the Add Package sheet, which shows the URL for the BuildABuddyKit GitHub repository in the search field. The search field, the BuildABuddyKit search result, the Dependency Rule, the Add to Project field, and the Add Package button are highlighted.")
Add BuildABuddyKit's package product to the BuddyCreator target and select "Add Package".

@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-06.png, alt: "A screenshot of the Add Package showing the BuildABuddyKit package product being added to the BuddyCreator target. BuildABuddyKit's package product, the BuddyCreator target, and the Add Package button are highlighted.")
Create an instance of `Buddy` and customize it.
Add a private property named `buddy` that returns an instance of `Buddy`.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-07.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a globe icon and the text \"Hello, world!\".")
Add a `BuddyImage` and pass it the value of `buddy`.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-08.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy.")
Start customizing the buddy by changing the skin tone.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-09.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a changed skin tone.")
Change the hair of the buddy.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-10.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with changed hair.")
Change the mouth of the buddy.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-11.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a changed mouth.")
Notice that the color of the front of the shirt and the color of the sleeves can be specified independently.
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-12.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with a new shirt.")
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-13.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with new pants.")
@Image(source: 01-customizing-a-buddy-01-14.png, alt: "A screenshot of the iPhone simulator showing a buddy with new shoes.")
